text: Hey Jon I've looked over that shot you sent a couple of times and it doesn't look like it's working at all. You are frameholding your patches right? If the patches are sliding the first thing I'm thinking is that your card is not in the correct place. in regards to the floor, are you using a separate card on the floor compared to the card your projecting on the back wall? There is a patch sliding around the sandwitch board? Like I said yesterday, I would just roto this back on top of the patches, maybe using an edge extend in the a pipe so you dont get the people walking in the background coming back through. You've kept the woman with the long hair in, but I can bits of black from the background creeping back in as she walks past

Hey there Rob, Sorry for the delayed reply - 2 job interviews today - coffee shop and the remote roto / rep clean up I mentioned previously.

Thanks for looking at the alley shot again. And for the comments. I want to start again with it with just 2d tracks and roto the sandwich board as you suggest. A classmate helped me put the projections in place but I don't fully understand the set up or why my patches are slipping - probably my tracks.  Waiting for the Hugo Guerra projections lessons to get a grip of that.
Thanks for the edge extend tip - not tried that before. May need to put it on hold to concentrate on any paid work that comes but will def get back to it.
good luck with the job interviews, fingers crossed. In regards to the projections, have you watched the Foundry's own videos on projection. I found them to be really good from memory

attachments.title: CameraTracker Node Basics
attachments.text: John Starck covers the basics of tracking and solving, lens distortion, and stereo solving using Nuke's CameraTracker node.
